content.p: high hopes
bloodiest wars
human history
catastrophes

The unparalleled bloodshed of World War II reached America through the greatest disaster in U.S. military history, the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Away from the battlefields, more than 6 million were murdered in the Nazi Holocaust. And the second half of the century was marred by Vietnam, the first war lost by the United States.
a century of big government
bloody totalitarian murderous government

q.name: But this has been the blight o..

content.p: But this has been the blight of this century: too much government.

q.name: I think one of the catastrophe..

content.p: I think one of the catastrophes is that it became fashionable to say, get government off our backs, let's have smaller government, forgetting all the things that government does that we can't do for ourselves and does for people who aren't in your position to accomplish it on their own.

isolationist Congress -- that I'm sure you approve of -- in the 1930s that's recreated in some segments of this Congress and Pat Buchanan that would keep us from doing anything other than exactly the selfish aims that we have for ourselves, the filibusters of the -- of 1964 against civil rights, Joe McCarthy, the assassinations that
anxiety we have about terrorism
particular form of government that scarred this century

, which was the Bolsheviks coming to power in Russia in 1917. From that, over time half the world's population was enslaved between the Soviet Union and China. Led to the death of tens of millions of peopl

q.name: But I think any regime that ha..

content.p: But I think any regime that had the devastating result on tens of millions of people has to be the largest catastrophe we faced.
great evil
progressive income ta
faith
material advancements
Eight percent of Americans had electricity at the turn of the century

Our life expectancy was increased 30 years. One in 10 children used to die before their first birthday. And not only are mothers spared that enormous heartache, but every time my own mother welcomed one of her 12 grandchildren, she would remind my three sisters and me about disposable diapers and disposable bottles, and umbrella strollers
The microwave

q.name: The car, the TV, the fax machi..

content.p: The car, the TV, the fax machine has spread democracy.

But Al's talking about freedom, because your definition of democracy, Al, at the century you'd say the United States wasn't a full democracy because... HUNT: No. Blacks couldn't vote, women couldn't vote.

q.name: the only thing we have to fear..

content.p: the only thing we have to fear is fear itself
heroes

q.name: But my heroes for the century ..

content.p: But my heroes for the century would be the American G.I. FDR and Churchill, both fine choices with respect to enormous contributions in the century, wouldn't have been able to do what they did without the American G.I., both the World War II generation, those who fought there, like my own father, their fathers who fought in World War I, the often-forgotten G.I.'s of Korea, and the often unfairly defiled G.I.'s of Vietnam. I mean, the American G.I. really made the -- this an American century.

q.name: You know, my teenage son took ..

content.p: You know, my teenage son took a course in 20th century heroes and I was struck by the fore that they focused in on Diedrik Bonjoffer (ph), the German theologian who resisted the Nazis and lost his life, George Marshall, the most unselfish and maybe greatest public servant of our century, Jackie Robinson, that valiant warrior who, facing incredible pressure and bigotry, integrated Major League Baseball, and Yien Chang (ph), the fragile but brave Chinese woman who spent years in a Shanghai prison torture because we shouldn't buckle under -- to the commies.

Franklin Roosevelt. No question about it. I mean, he is a towering figure. He did save free enterprise. He saved democracy at a time when totalitarianism and the sense of impatience with the inability -- when the country lost half of its gross national product...

q.name: Hitler, Stalin, Mao. Pol Pot k..

content.p: Hitler, Stalin, Mao. Pol Pot killed 1.7 million people

q.name: For the second half of the cen..

content.p: For the second half of the century, the Supreme Court and other federal judges have found invisible writing in the federal Constitution to justify judicial tyranny preventing school prayer, managing schools, interfering with private business, preventing term limits, and worst of all, prohibiting state legislatures from regulating abortion.
class system

q.name: A century marked by great adva..

content.p: A century marked by great advancements in the material well being of the human race was also marked by a terrible death toll. The casualties, the world wars, the Holocaust, Cambodia's killing fields, and Rwanda. But the most horrific loss of life has been the deliberate destruction of 35 million innocents in the U.S. alone through abortion. As predicted 25 years ago, abortion on demand has ushered in a culture of death and has corrupted our constitutional principles.

Mark, it took almost two-thirds of the American century to give black Americans the basic right to vote, eat in a restaurant or buy a home of their choice. It is our national shame that it took this great country so long to start living up to our ideals of equality, justice and freedom.
America's cities burned in 1967 racial rioting
top-down management

q.name: But hey, we won, it seems

content.p: But hey, we won, it seems
Liberalism, in a sense, won
freedom of the press, freedom of religion
longest peacetime economic expansion in history
Totalitarianism
Totalitarianism up to a point does work. It eventually implodes, but it -- you know, you can control an awful lot of people for an awful long time
Gerald Ford

q.name: Gerald Ford is the one who did..

content.p: Gerald Ford is the one who did the best job when we needed it most. I mean, he healed a country that was terribly torn apart

q.name: And we sometimes put too much ..

content.p: And we sometimes put too much emphasis on them

q.name: one thing you could say about ..

content.p: one thing you could say about the 20th Century is that the presidency has become probably too large an office
Dr. Albert Einstein
Churchill

q.name: Oh, I would have chosen Church..

content.p: Oh, I would have chosen Churchill, those absolutely desperate days when England stood alone against Hitler. And had -- and had Churchill not prevailed, the world would have been so different, so utterly different

q.name: And science is going to be mor..

content.p: And science is going to be more a part of our lives than it has ever been in the past. They're just the -- the Internet -- I've just -- I've been involved with this Y2K issue for the last three years or so

q.name: have to learn to deal with sci..

content.p: have to learn to deal with scientific created forms of life.
Theoretically, it is now possible to manipulate the human genes in each one of those people, and genetic codes can be manipulated
manipulating and the controlling

q.name: Good men or evil men -- we wil..

content.p: Good men or evil men -- we will be manipulated without knowing it. I see the new technology making possible unimaginable evil in the world

q.name: will it be good men or will it..

content.p: will it be good men or will it be bad men?
ethic
Hampering with a woman's eggs or a man's sperm, I mean, that's what they can do now
change the chromosomes

q.name: We have been working with jell..

content.p: We have been working with jelly fish and once you do (ph) those early things, the next stop is just a matter of time and sequence. We are not ready for that. And we had better do, or it will tear us apart
single parents
educated population all across the spectrum of American ethnic groups and regional groups and such like

q.name: Right now, we have a world in ..

content.p: Right now, we have a world in which a clearly delineated upward mobile group is getting educated quickly, fast, roaring ahead, and other groups not moving along at all. And that can produce a division unlike anything we've known
nuclear weapon migrating to the Middle East. It will migrate
Martin Luther King address from the memorial, the "I Have a Dream" speech during the march on Washington

q.name: it's a message of peace that t..

content.p: it's a message of peace that the world have to keep every year in mind and to repeat it, but not forgetting it

q.name: Chicago is a country that has ..

content.p: Chicago is a country that has done so well in computer and understands the technology of the new computer. So I am not surprised at all

q.name: New Orleans and places like Gr..

content.p: New Orleans and places like Granbury, Texas. Our own Candy Crowley's there. We're going to be visiting a part of Texas close to Dallas
And also, in this hemisphere, Mexico City. And to the north, Winnipeg in Canada, and in Central America, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua, waiting to welcome the millennium

q.name: No, no, I know. But, you know,..

content.p: No, no, I know. But, you know, we keep showing these pictures of New York and Washington, but we should say, Bernie, there are 20 states and Washington, plus two other parts of two other states that are now in the year 2000. I don't know if we have time to name them all - Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, West Virginia, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Michigan, Georgia, Indiana, Connecticut, Maryland, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Delaware, Florida, New York and parts of Kentucky and Tennessee. Those states are in two time zones.

q.name: world is still in one piece

content.p: world is still in one piece
And despite earlier fears, no major acts of terrorism have been reported here in the United States or elsewhere in the world.

Afghanistan, actually, Russians woke up Saturday to a new century and a new president. Vladimir Putin, who took over as acting president after Boris Yeltsin's surprise resignation Friday, skipped a fancy ball in Moscow to visit Russian troops on the front lines in Chechnya. And CNN's Alessio Vinci has more now on the dramatic turn of events in Russia.
Awarding troops with hunting knives, he told soldiers fighting separatist militants that their task was to keep the Russian Federation together

q.name: It's about putting an end to R..

content.p: It's about putting an end to Russia falling apart
After years of economic hardship and failed promises of a better life, Vladimir Putin will have to restore some confidence in the Russian people.

q.name: Hoping for a better future, Ru..

content.p: Hoping for a better future, Russians came to Red Square to celebrate the new millennium and the most significant political change in almost a decade.

q.name: Some already assume life in Ru..

content.p: Some already assume life in Russia with Putin as president will be better
Education will improve. Things will get just great

q.name: After a very late night, Pope ..

content.p: After a very late night, Pope John Paul II has been appearing to lead Mass at one of Rome's major churches, which concluded just a short time ago. Usually on January 1, the Pope has in the past used St. Peter's Basilica for the New Year's Day Mass, but today he switched to not only lead the Mass at St. Mary Major Church in the center of ancient Rome but also to open another of the giant holy doors, which are a significant part of this special 2000 holy year.

At Santa Maria Maggiore, Mary Major Basilica, the Pope opened a third of the four holy doors after those at St. Peter's on Christmas Eve and the Lateranen Basilica on Christmas Day. The holy doors of Rome's four basilicas are only opened during rare holy year celebrations. He'll push the fourth at San Paolo Fuori Le Mura on January 18.

Now, the Pope who led Mass, as I say, concluded a short time ago, and he will be making an address to Rome and the world later on before the Rome marathon, which will have tens of thousands of participants, kicks off in the center of Rome.

People have been looking at the appearance of the Pope, who just a few days ago came out through St. Peter's Basilica being wheeled through the giant arena on a chariot pushed by two Vatican ushers. Today, at the New Year's Day Mass, the Pope left just within the past 20 minutes walking through the basilica with the help of aides and waving and smiling, preparing for his next event, which will be the address and then kicking off the Rome marathon.

q.name: I think that right now for Put..

content.p: I think that right now for Putin the election campaign will be the most important thing. If and when he is elected as president of the Russian Federation and once he has the public mandate, then we will see some changes. And definitely he will have to distance himself from Yeltsin.

VINCI: But only hours after becoming acting president, Putin signed a decree giving Boris Yeltsin immunity from legal prosecution, a clear sign that Russia's new leader will not allow any witch hunt that could destabilize the country. After years of economic hardship and failed promises of a better life, Vladimir Putin will have to restore some confidence in the Russian people.
(on camera): Hoping for a better future, Russians came to Red Square to celebrate the new millennium and the most significant political change in almost a decade.
(voice-over): Some already assume life in Russia with Putin as president will be better.
UNIDENTIFIED RUSSIAN: I think we'll get paid and we'll have work. We'll have a good army. Education will improve. Things will get just great.
VINCI: For these Russians in their first day of the new millennium things appeared, indeed, just great.
Alessio Vinci, CNN, Moscow.
Thanks, Colleen.

After a very late night, Pope John Paul II has been appearing to lead Mass at one of Rome's major churches, which concluded just a short time ago. Usually on January 1, the Pope has in the past used St. Peter's Basilica for the New Year's Day Mass, but today he switched to not only lead the Mass at St. Mary Major Church in the center of ancient Rome but also to open another of the giant holy doors, which are a significant part of this special 2000 holy year.

At Santa Maria Maggiore, Mary Major Basilica, the Pope opened a third of the four holy doors after those at St. Peter's on Christmas Eve and the Lateranen Basilica on Christmas Day. The holy doors of Rome's four basilicas are only opened during rare holy year celebrations. He'll push the fourth at San Paolo Fuori Le Mura on January 18.

Now, the Pope who led Mass, as I say, concluded a short time ago, and he will be making an address to Rome and the world later on before the Rome marathon, which will have tens of thousands of participants, kicks off in the center of Rome.

People have been looking at the appearance of the Pope, who just a few days ago came out through St. Peter's Basilica being wheeled through the giant arena on a chariot pushed by two Vatican ushers. Today, at the New Year's Day Mass, the Pope left just within the past 20 minutes walking through the basilica with the help of aides and waving and smiling, preparing for his next event, which will be the address and then kicking off the Rome marathon.
Colleen?

Doctors in the field hospital here in western Chechnya say they are treating 40 to 60 wounded a day depending on the fighting, and with just two surgeons here that means a great deal of work to get done.

q.name: Quite a celebration on the str..

content.p: Quite a celebration on the streets of Seoul. It's been very crowded here. This really marking a new millennium, a lot of the hopes for South Korea to regain some of its economic strength

q.name: There's a big celebration by C..

content.p: There's a big celebration by Capetown at Robben Island, which of course has great significance to the South African leadership.
world's humanity
Pentagon's ability to communicate with that intelligence system

q.name: The glitch amounted to a tempo..

content.p: The glitch amounted to a temporary interruption in the Pentagon's ability to communicate with that intelligence system. That problem has now had a temporary fix put in place. They are now working on a more permanent one.
The Pentagon had -- had been anticipating a problem with this system going into Y2K as it had with many other systems. It had put a patch in place. Apparently, that patch may have not taken.

Otherwise, however, the Pentagon says it has had a pretty good rollover into the new year, no major problems, no minor problems. There was one problem going into the Middle East with a communications system there, and they're saying that that was not Y2K related.
an unprecedented, historic, cooperative effort between the United States and Russia
problem that could accidentally trigger a nuclear confrontation
Russian officers and American officers

The cooperation and the facility itself here is looked upon as a role model for a permanent facility to be located in Moscow, to be manned 365 days a year, 24 hours a day by Americans and Russians with the prospect and hope that the possibility of any accidental nuclear confrontation like the Cold War itself will be relegated to the past

content.p: F-4 Phantom jet from the Vietnam War
